content: Recently, we heard about the invention of ChatGPT. The first enthusiasm seems to end in sobriety. Realizing that the best can be the enemy of the goodThe news that the BlackMamba keylogger has appeared on the web is not at all rosy. This keylogger can spread over the internet and adapts to the needs of each victim.The spy collects personal information, including passwords and user card data, and it is possible that it can target crypto users, waiting for the possibility of stealing seed phrases and passwords."The BlackMamba threat is also compatible with Windows, Linux, and even Mac, which are famous for their high security, so it is important for users on all devices to be careful."https://www.hackread.com/chatgpt-blackmamba-malware-keylogger/In addition, there is a second unpleasant story about the "successes" of ChatGPT. This tool attacks our passwords.How secure do you think your passwords are?You can check it out by following this link.https://www.homesecurityheroes.com/ai-password-cracking/

comments.author: _act_
comments.body: One thing that I found out recently is that AI technology, machine learning and others like that which are AI is the beginning to the end of privacy, I hope people will know this as early as possible.ChatGPT is using information from other sources without any reference and yet stealing people's information. Another one again that malware is also becoming reality through using ChatGPT. I do not see any good reason to use ChatGPT for now, but I am really discourage again and again.

comments.author: Pmalek
comments.body: ChatGPT won't create or provide answers to anything that is illegal or what it is programmed to deem illegal. But the problem is, you just need to tweak your question or request a little bit and what was initially unacceptable is suddenly fine and OK according to their TOS. I am sure that's how people trick the AI to make it create such code for them.I wouldn't recommend that anyone enter their actual passwords on https://www.homesecurityheroes.com/ai-password-cracking/. But you can enter something similar if you are really curious. A password made up of lowercase and uppercase letters, numbers, and special characters would take billions of years to bruteforce according to that site. And they are pretty easy to generate.
